text: Fast Fact: In-network Coinsurance is The percent (for example, 20%) you pay of the allowed amount for covered health care services to providers who contract with your health insurance or plan. In-network coinsurance usually costs you less than out-of-network coinsurance. https://t.co/taStQb18Rq

like my coinsurance is 10%….. i literally would have to pay 10 times the amount, payment in full, to see someone out of network. it’s so ridiculous.

@Christorical But then you’d also want to compare PPO and HMO networks. For me, they are the same network but premiums are different, so after the PPO deductible, it’s mostly a wash. If I have a major procedure and have to pay PPO coinsurance, then the HMO would become the better option. 3/

@Christorical By no means an expert, but in my experience, it really depends on all the plan variables, alternatives, and your needs. PVs: monthly premium, annual deductible, coinsurance, rx coverage, and annual out-of-pocket maximum. Can try to explain each of these terms if helpful. 1/

@nacholibraa69 Facts. Read up on coinsurance, check deductibles and co-pays for each, compare them and that is a good baseline I've found. If you travel or see specialists then in-network vs out is a consideration too

admitting to the ombudsmen to financial assistance to analyzing the data. It is no wonder why our health care system is such a mess with such needless bureaucracy. Each employer has their own health care provider, with different coverages, co-pays, deductibles, coinsurance, ...

@RobertT13960924 @UFCxPlayStation @David_Slotnick And let’s not talk about coinsurance. Imagine paying 2400 a year to an insurance company and they take that money and only partially pay for your medical expenses and keep the rest, forcing you to pay the rest
@RobertT13960924 @UFCxPlayStation @David_Slotnick I’m not talking JUST about premiums. I’m talking about all of those expenses. Coinsurance too. Deductibles.

@RobertT13960924 @UFCxPlayStation @David_Slotnick And by that I mean you won’t have to worry about deductibles/copays/premiums/coinsurance and then having to pay even more medical bills that your insurance won’t pay. Just a tax increase and you get to walk into any hospital, any time, dont have to worry if it’s in network or not

@RobertT13960924 @UFCxPlayStation @David_Slotnick Good for you, you can afford health insurance and the deductibles and the copayments and the coinsurance. Your taxes go towards improving everyone’s access to healthcare, not just yours. This is what I mean when I say Americans are selfish. It’s always “what about me”

@rosiegirlygirl @Rozalyn29450275 @sspencer_smb @David_Slotnick Bcbs has a 5k deductible with a 20% coinsurance which is separate from the deductible. The out of pocket max is kinda high too.... 100k birrh would easily give you that 12k. Which would come with any sort of nicu stay for baby

@declairemoore @ATWlover13 @Plasmic_Saul @David_Slotnick So if you had a $100 bill and had $50 remaining on your deductible you’d be responsible for that $50 plus whatever the coinsurance would be. So if your insurance is 80/20 - you’d also be responsible for 20% of that $50 meaning in total you’d owe $60 of that $100 responsibility.
@VoteBond19 @jlms_qkw I noticed that the online coupons (Good Price) are cheaper than what the coinsurance would be thru my insurance. Bizarre!

@politicalmath my employer pays 90% of premium, I pay 10%
in early 2000's when I had my kids, I had a "Cadillac plan"- zero deductible, zero coinsurance- zero bill

@David_Slotnick Unfortunately, most people don't have even close to "good" insurance. First you'll have a deductible of $5K, then anything the insurance co. decides they don't cover, and then a 20% coinsurance, but that's okay because many plans will cap your out-of-pocket at $7500.  No prob.

@1Objectivist @FactsSetUFree @RBReich How much do you know about Medicare? Non-Medicaid patients pay significant premiums & coinsurance. The health spending is likely also related to the govt subsidizing health plans/payers in other ways (not all Medicare spending).

@pastajoe5 @PrerunnerPilot @JHitchcock99 @SpeakerPelosi @HouseDemocrats No.  It has killed way more people than it has saved. People who can't afford healthcare die preventable deaths because they can't afford to pay their deductibles and coinsurance.  I know because I'm one of them.

@SpeakerPelosi @HouseDemocrats Thanks to the ACA, health insurance for *everyone is more expensive and delivers less than it ever did 20 or 30 years ago. Deductibles, co-pays and coinsurance weren't even in the common vernacular in the 90s, unless you purchased a catastrophic plan. 

*not indigent

A key number on your health insurance policy is the out-of-pocket limit. This is the maximum amount that you will pay for covered services in a single year. Depending on the plan, it might or might not include the deductible, coinsurance, or copays.

@Christorical But then you’d also want to compare PPO and HMO networks. For me, they are the same network but premiums are different, so after the PPO deductible, it’s mostly a wash. If I have a major procedure and have to pay PPO coinsurance, then the HMO would become the better option. 3/

@Christorical By no means an expert, but in my experience, it really depends on all the plan variables, alternatives, and your needs. PVs: monthly premium, annual deductible, coinsurance, rx coverage, and annual out-of-pocket maximum. Can try to explain each of these terms if helpful. 1/
